response: No idea, man.
A true idiot of I ever saw one
This scheme of his is so hairbrained that I'm surprised he got past step one. I'd expect him to break his skull tripping over the door mat of the pawn shop where he bought that sawed-off
This is all assuming he's guilty, of course. Hopefully he's not.
I heard once that some people try to keep themselves anonmymous when they win the lottery. That way they don't have a thousand relatives bashing down their doors asking for money.
Maybe the victim should have taken that advice and applied it to her recent windfall.
Though I don't think anyone could have predicted someone would take measures this drastic.
Okay, so I'm a bit squeamish. When I saw those photos of his bloodied face after the alleged assault, I was cringing backward through time!
I do find the timeline a bit odd though. The officer mentions getting punched in the face, but then the other officer testified and I think I remember him saying the defendant was already in cuffs.
How can you throw a punch when you're in cuffs? Let along enough to cause that much blood.
I dunno.
I'm probably misremembering.
Gotta keep the people in line somehow.
This is what gets me: How dumb does the prosecution think the defendant is? The only way this supposed scheme of his works is if he inherits the money from his girlfriend after she dies.
But that only works if they're married. The entire motive for this case hinges on the defendant not knowing even the very basics of inheritance law.
The coworker's testimony seemed...aggressive?
Like he was relishing in being able to testify against him.
From what I recall from the trial, the defendant went over the coworker's head regarding some major company project.
His prints are the only ones on the gun. But if someone else killed the victim, they could have used gloves.
If I were committing a murder with someone else's gun with intention of then leaving said gun at the crime scene, I would use gloves.

text: Why don't we get going here?
I think we should talk about the motive here.

I think we should talk about the motive here. The whole bit about wanting to kill his girlfriend for the inheritance seems shaky to me. They weren't married, so he wouldn't have gotten the money no matter what.
Even if he had gotten away with it, how was he thinking he would get his money?
The whole bit about wanting to kill his girlfriend for the inheritance seems shaky to me. They weren't married, so he wouldn't have gotten the money no matter what.
Even if he had gotten away with it, how was he thinking he would get his money?
I just don't buy it. They weren't married, so he wouldn't have gotten the money no matter what.
Even if he had gotten away with it, how was he thinking he would get his money?

Even if he was willing to kill his girlfriend for the money, they weren't married. The money wouldn't have been his even if he had gotten away with it. He would have to be real dumb to think this sort of scheme would work.
You think he went out and bought a shotgun just to waste his old lady? If I were gonna kill someone, that wouldn't be my weapon of choice. Just saying.

Absolutely. And the prosecution was never able to prove that he bought it beforehand. They just talked about how he didn't have a receipt for it. But it's like, "Hey buddy, proving things is your job!"
It's not on the defense to prove anything!
Absolutely. And the prosecution was never able to prove that he bought it beforehand. They just talked about how he didn't have a receipt for it.
And nobody else's prints were found on the gun. Just his.
They could have used gloves so that their prints wouldn't end up on the gun.
Hell if I know.
So what's it worth now?
Absolutely.
I had to look away when they showed those pictures of him. So much blood.
According to that testimony, there were no other officers around. And officer Young was still reeling from the blow when officer Grady arrived.
He must have been cuffed already when the alleged punch took place.
What, do people not normally bleed that much when socked in the face? I've seen someone bleed that much before.
Well I think I have.
I did pass out pretty soon after.
What's that bit? "Beyond a reasonable doubt?"
I have reason to doubt that that guy could knock out my aunt Fanny, let alone an experienced man of the law.
He mentioned something during cross examination about a company project and that he would be taking over.
The coworker mentioned something during cross examination about a company project and that he would be taking over.
You don't think he lied to get the defendant off the project, do you?
Get him indicted on murder so the big wigs fire him and put him in charge instead?

acquitEntirely: Against all odds, he seems to be innocent.
acquitInheritance: I don't think he fired the gun and the apparent motive seems completely bogus.
acquitCoworker: I don't think he fired the gun and his alibi seems to check out.
chargeWithAssault: He did still assault a police officer, even if he is innocent of murder.
guiltyShotgun: There's too much evidence that he fired the gun, regardless of whether the motive makes sense.
guiltyMotivePlusOpportunity: I still can't believe he was dumb enough to think he could get that inheritance money, but all the facts point to that being the case. Plus he was there at the scene of the crime.
